articles.headline: Trump Considers Rolling Back Obama’s Opening With Cuba
articles.snippet: Clamping down on engagement with Cuba would allow Mr. Trump to fulfill a campaign pledge to Cuban-Americans, who disproportionately supported him.
articles.abstract: Clamping down on engagement with Cuba would allow Mr. Trump to fulfill a campaign pledge to Cuban-Americans, who disproportionately supported him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is considering reversing major pieces of the Obama administration’s opening with Cuba and reinstating limits on travel and commerce, citing human rights abuses by the Castro government as justification for a more punitive approach.

articles.headline: Less Tweeting, Lawyers Beg. ‘Covfefe,’ the President Says.
articles.snippet: During the campaign and the early months of his presidency, the concern over Mr. Trump’s Twitter use was political. Now the worry is increasingly legal.
articles.abstract: During the campaign and the early months of his presidency, the concern over Mr. Trump’s Twitter use was political. Now the worry is increasingly legal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There was a time in the not-too-distant past when President Trump refrained from flamethrowing messages on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Steady Jobs, With Pay and Hours That Are Anything But
articles.snippet: Volatile wages, owing in part to undependable schedules, are one factor increasing economic anxiety even with unemployment at a post-recession low.
articles.abstract: Volatile wages, owing in part to undependable schedules, are one factor increasing economic anxiety even with unemployment at a post-recession low.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mirella Casares has what used to be considered the keystone of economic security: a job. But even a reliable paycheck no longer delivers a reliable income.

articles.headline: Chinese Maker of Ivanka Trump’s Shoes Looks for Cheaper Labor
articles.snippet: As workers in China complain of excessive hours and seek higher pay, the factory owner is sending more jobs to Africa.
articles.abstract: As workers in China complain of excessive hours and seek higher pay, the factory owner is sending more jobs to Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — The Chinese factory workers who make shoes for Ivanka Trump and other designers gather at 7:40 every morning to sing songs.

articles.headline: Why Troubles at a Midsize Italian Bank Worry the E.U.
articles.snippet: The health of Monte dei Paschi — as assessed by the European Central Bank — will be the crucial measure to ensure the bailout follows new regulations.
articles.abstract: The health of Monte dei Paschi — as assessed by the European Central Bank — will be the crucial measure to ensure the bailout follows new regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Some banks go to the international markets when they need money for a big deal. Monte dei Paschi di Siena, one of Italy’s biggest lenders, tapped its own loyal customers.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Gaia Pianigiani and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Maybe Private Russian Hackers Meddled in Election, Putin Says
articles.snippet: The Russian president denied any state role, but said that cyberattacks might have been the work of private citizens. “Anything is possible in this virtual world,” Mr. Putin said
articles.abstract: The Russian president denied any state role, but said that cyberattacks might have been the work of private citizens. “Anything is possible in this virtual world,” Mr. Putin said
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Shifting from his previous blanket denials, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested on Thursday that “patriotically minded” private Russian hackers could have been involved in cyberattacks last year that meddled in the United States presidential election.

articles.headline: Trump Rule Could Deny Birth Control Coverage to Hundreds of Thousands of Women
articles.snippet: A new rule nearing approval would greatly expand the number of employers and insurers that could claim moral objections to contraception coverage.
articles.abstract: A new rule nearing approval would greatly expand the number of employers and insurers that could claim moral objections to contraception coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has drafted a sweeping revision of the government’s contraception coverage mandate that could deny birth control benefits to hundreds of thousands of women who now receive them at no cost under the Affordable Care Act.
